intro: Rhododendron molle subsp. japonicum, commonly known as the Japanese azalea, is a deciduous shrub native to eastern Asia. It is characterized by its clusters of showy, pink to white flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters and has lance-shaped leaves that are dark green and glossy. It prefers acidic, well-drained soil and partial to full sun, making it a popular ornamental plant in gardens. Its botanical features include hairy stems and showy bracts that enhance its visual appeal.
